name: Letter from Lipsius, Justus to Clusius, Carolus, 1591-04-21

Diplomatic.text: Mi Clusi, Ego delibero an in his locis diutius manebo. Multa me absterrent, sed inprimis quod hospitia haec in ista valetudine non fero. Morti mihi sunt. Itaque statui ad Spadanos potius fontes me conferre, quanquam id quoque sine discrimine aut molestia non fiet. Si quid igitur litterarum alicunde ad me, rogo uti Coloniam ad Arnoldum Mylium cures. Eum ego conveniam et cum illo constituam quo mittat. Amicos saluto, inprimis D[ominum] Pellissonium et D[ominum] Morlassium Gallos, si eos vides. Mi Clusi vale, quem ego rebus et valetudine melioribus spero iterum visurum et magis fruiturum. Moguntiaci, XI Kal[endas] Maiias M.D.XCI. Tuus I[ustus] Lipsius. Frans Francken D[edi]. [Address:] Clarissimo et doctissimo viro Carolo Clusio. Francofurtum by de Craneporte, chez un hoste de Gorcum. [Manu Clusii] 1591. I[usti] Lips[ii], Moguntiaci, XI K[a]l[endas] Maiias Greg[orii] calc[uli]. Accepi Francofurti, VI K[a]l[endas] Maiias eiusdem calculi.

annotations.text: Morlassium: Jean de Morlas († Mâcon, 27 August 1595) was the natural son of Salettes, president of the parliament of Pau. From 1589 on, he became one of the most active agents of Henry of Navarra, whom he strongly urged to convert to Catholicism, as he did himself. Navarra appointed him member of his Private Council and of the State Council. Cf. Haag, 7, 509-510.

annotations.text: Pellissonium: Pierre Pélisson, a confirmed Protestant, was councellor and master of requests of the king of Navarra from 16 February 1582 on. He had married Jeanne du Bourg and is author of a pamphlet, Propositions du sieur Du Perron, évêque d’Evreux sur les marques et authorités de l’Eglise etc. avec la réponse du sieur Pélisson, conseiller du roy et maître des requêtes de l’hotel de Navarre (Sedan, 1617). Cf. Haag, La France protestante, 8, 170-171.
